topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Hamilton Helmer, his book 7 Powers, and what they’ll cover: when to think about power, common misconceptions, how to apply the framework, and AI’s impact on defensibility.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS and Vanta, covering enterprise auth/compliance tooling and security/compliance automation.

topics.title: When founders should think about power
topics.summary: Helmer explains his updated view: strategy and power are worth considering even pre–product-market fit, not as rigid planning but as probability-tilting choices that affect the availability of power across a company’s lifecycle and “second acts.”

topics.title: Defining strategy and linking it to value
topics.summary: Helmer narrows “strategy” to what drives business value (NPV of future cash flows), emphasizing strategy’s long time horizon and distinguishing it from short-term tactics using Pearl Harbor as an analogy.

topics.title: What power is: benefit plus barrier
topics.summary: They unpack power as durable advantage requiring both a benefit (price/cost advantage) and a barrier (inimitability), with Netflix’s scale economies as a concrete example.

topics.title: Power progression and early-stage power options
topics.summary: Helmer describes “power progression,” arguing early startups should largely ignore brand/process/resource power and focus on counter-positioning first, then potentially scale economies, switching costs, and network economies as they grow.

topics.title: Common moat mistakes: brand, data, flywheels
topics.summary: Helmer explains why founders often misdiagnose power: brand awareness can be bought, data scale economies are rarer than claimed, and many “flywheels” exist but aren’t materially strong enough to create durable advantage.

topics.title: Network effects vs network economies (materiality)
topics.summary: Helmer distinguishes weak network effects from true network-economy power by insisting on material impact on pricing/margins; he cites Uber/Lyft as likely having some network effects but not strong enough to be power.

topics.title: Moats vs power and the Netflix “castle” test
topics.summary: Helmer clarifies that a moat is closer to the barrier component, while power requires both barrier and meaningful value (“castle not shack”); he uses Netflix UI/recommendations as important but largely mimickable capabilities.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Paragon, an embedded integrations platform for B2B SaaS teams to ship integrations faster than building in-house.

topics.title: Applying power thinking as a product manager
topics.summary: Helmer advises IC PMs to understand their company’s source of power, surface on-the-ground insights that protect it, and adapt quickly during the takeoff phase as technology waves create new features and segments.

topics.title: How to build strategic thinking skills
topics.summary: Helmer recommends reading, then pressure-testing ideas through conversations with colleagues about what power the business truly has; he shares how Netflix once trained leaders in strategy but he no longer runs full courses.

topics.title: AI’s impact on power and business models
topics.summary: Helmer argues AI doesn’t add an “eighth power,” but it can amplify existing powers (scale, switching costs, network learning) and will likely have broad “electricity-like” impact across many existing industries and functions.

topics.title: Why execution/process is rarely a durable power
topics.summary: Building on Porter’s “operational excellence is not strategy,” Helmer explains execution is essential (especially in takeoff) but usually imitable; true process power requires material, opaque, hard-to-copy know-how (e.g., Toyota/TSMC-like complexity).

topics.title: Macro outlook: debt risk and entrepreneurship optimism
topics.summary: Helmer warns that rising sovereign debt could reduce crisis “dry powder,” tightening capital markets and making founding harder, but closes with optimism that entrepreneurs drive economic vitality (Schumpeter) and urges action as the first principle.
